data.text: @Fiskadoro74 @TDesOrmeau @nwarikoo Maybe not exactly analogous, but here's Ontario's data. FYI, about 85% of Ontarians age 5+ have 2 doses. https://t.co/mYxYOZ8rnj

@Fiskadoro74 @nwarikoo That's interesting.

Some hospitals are sharing their ratios on their social media. For example, at Henry Ford right now, the split is pretty even (since there are more vaxxed people in Michigan), although there are very few *boosted* people hospitalized. https://t.co/W4J96CWK51

@TDesOrmeau @nwarikoo Yeah wondering because my sister's an ER nurse and says it's still been nearly all unvaccinated people through Omicron. Interesting the transmission gap closed so wildly though. Ye olde herd immunity at work.
@Fiskadoro74 @nwarikoo I wish we could. The data from the CDC and MDHHS only shows cases and deaths.
@TDesOrmeau @nwarikoo Ok can we do one for hospitalizations?

To see the interactive graphics and read more on this, check out our story.
https://t.co/IKz7X4NeyM

Here's another way to look at it: Cases and deaths per capita for vaccinated people vs. unvaccinated people.

Every single week, vaccinated people catch COVID and die from it at a lower rate than unvaccinated people. https://t.co/Ha7ochd2lf

But it's a different story for deaths.

If anything, the booster was *more* effective vs. omicron than previous strains, according to Michigan data.

People with the booster were 84x less likely to die from COVID than unvaccinated people (in the most recent weeks of data). https://t.co/RSQfAIFw2R
